name: State_0

timeline_beats.label: Early delta settlement and coastal harbors established
Integration into river-league trade networks; guild rise
Fragmentation during Age of Flux; local houses and rites consolidate
Border settlement, Lowland Cession and legal codification

factions.label: River-Guild Council
factions.influence_hint: Controls major ports, trade licenses, and reagent imports

factions.label: Lowland Houses
factions.influence_hint: Landed elite; taxation and militia in interior plains

factions.label: Saltworkers' Syndicate
factions.influence_hint: Monopoly on saltworks and seasonal labor; local political leverage

factions.label: Cabinet of Ancestors
factions.influence_hint: Clerical-ritual authority; regulatory role over permitted magic

traits: oral navigational lore and seamanship rites
practical ritualism tied to material offerings

constraints: Tech baseline: near-medieval to early-industrial; no high-pressure steam megatechs
Ritual magic consumes scarce imported reagents; no true life-replacement or instant resurrection magics
Long-range mind influence is rare and institutionally banned within polity
Navigational auguries augment but do not replace charts and seamanship
Combustion-derived industry limited by fuel and craft constraints
Obligations under T2 (River Boundary Accord) and T4 (Migration and Settlement Protocol) must be honored
Alliance obligations to A3 constrain unilateral offensive actions; BC1 altered borders that remain legally binding
notes: Ritual reagent supply routed primarily via TB2 trade links; disruption -> sharp ritual/service shortages
Guilds (River-Guild, Saltworkers) effectively manage ports and customs; expect layered administrative control
Seasonal floods dictate planting/harvest cycles and militia mobilization timing
Border Meadow remains a flashpoint owing to W2 legacy and BC1; local militias active
No centralized high-pressure industrial infrastructure; manufacturing remains craft/guild-based
